REQUEST FOR EXPRESSIONS OF INTEREST

Country - India

Project - SUPPORTING ANDHRA'S LEARNING TRANSFORMATION PROGRAM

(P173978)

 

Assignment Title: Providing Technical Support for Foundational learning Reference No.: IN-SAMAGRA SHIKSHA-244987-CS-QCBS

 

1.The Department of School Education (DoSE), Government of Andhra Pradesh (GoAP) has applied for financing from the World Bank toward the cost of the SALT project and intends to apply part of the proceeds for consulting services.

2.The “Services” include supporting state institutions such as Samagra Shiksha State Implementation Society, SCERT and DoWCSSC in improving foundational learning in Anganwadis, preparatory classrooms, and grade-1 and -2 classes in primary schools. This would include developing a transformational roadmap, a package of ECE teaching-learning material, teacher capacity building platforms and orientation of education functionaries.

 

3.The Samagra Shiksha State Implementation Society now invites eligible non-government consultant services to indicate their interest in providing the services. This expression of Interest is only open to Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs). Interested NGO’s consultants should provide information demonstrating that they have the required qualifications and relevant experience to perform the Services. The short-listing criteria are:

    1. General experience of the Firm(s);
    2. Experience in similar projects of compatible size, complexity and technical specialty in the required area;
    3. Financial Soundness of the firm; and
    4. Staffing and logistics of the firm.

While indicating information relating to (b), it shall be made clear whether responsibility of the firm was in the capacity of a principal firm (lead partner) or as an associated firm (sub- consultant/JV partner) with detail scope of the service.

Consultants are requested to submit the following supporting documents against the above- mentioned criteria:(a) Registration paper of the firm(s); (b) JV agreement/letter of intent (if applicable); (c) Firm’s brochure; (d) Audited financial reports for last three years; (e) service experience record (including nature, total cost, total input in terms of staff month, employer, location of service, scope of services etc.). The experience of a parent company, subsidiary company, group company or associates (whatever the names) of the Applicant shall not be considered in evaluation.

 

4.The attention of interested Consultants is drawn to paragraphs 3.14, 3.16, and 3.17 of the “World Bank Procurement Regulations, 2016” for IPF Borrowers (Revised November 2020), setting forth the World Bank’s policy on conflict of interest.

5.Consultants may associate with other firms in the form of a joint venture or a sub- consultancy to enhance their qualifications. In the case of an association, all members of such “association” should have real and well-defined inputs to the assignment and the total  number of firms including their associates shall be maximum of three. In case of association in the form of sub-consultancy, the experience of sub-consultant shall not be considered in evaluation.

6.A Consultant will be selected in accordance with the Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) method as set out in Section VII, paragraph 7.3 of the World Bank’s “Procurement Regulations for IPF Borrowers” July 2016, revised August 2018 (“Procurement Regulations”).

7.The detailed Terms of Reference for the assignment can be found at the following web link.

              http://schooledu.ap.gov.in/Doc21/FL_EOI_word_final_27.07.2021.pdf

8.Further information can be obtained at the address below during office hours. Queries may also be mailed at  apssworldbank@apschooledu.in with the subject line – “Query _ECE Support Agency _<Name of the Firm>”. Please account for delays in response to queries.

9.Expressions of interest must be emailed/mailed at apssworldbank@apschooledu.in  with the subject line – “EoI_ ECE Support Agency _<Name of the firm>” by 23.45 Hrs 10.08.2021

Samagra Siksha K.Vetriselvi., IAS.

State Project Director, Samagra Siksha Beside KBC boys high school, Patamata,

Vijayawada.

Andhra Pradesh-520010 Tel: 9154294197

E-mail: apssworldbank@apschooledu.in

REQUEST FOR EXPRESSIONS OF INTEREST

 

Country - India

Project - SUPPORTING ANDHRA'S LEARNING TRANSFORMATION PROGRAM(P173978)

 

Assignment Title: Providing Technical Support to the Andhra Pradesh State Council of Educational Research and Training (SCERT)

 

Reference No.: IN-SAMAGRA SHIKSHA-211530-CS-QCBS

 

1. The Department of School Education (DoSE), Government of Andhra Pradesh (GoAP) has applied for financing from the World Bank toward the cost of theSALT project and intends to apply part of the proceeds for consulting services.

 

2. The “Services”include increasing the provision and quality of blended teacher professional development (TPD) opportunities (on-site teacher training, on-site and remote individual coaching, and online repository of training materials). This will involve building the capacity of SCERT and DIETs officials to improve planning, implementation, and monitoring of TPD opportunities, institutionalizing a teacher needs assessment system to formally encourage professional learning and growth, developing training courses for teachers on the state Learning Management System (LMS), and the development of online learning materials for students for at home learning. 

 

3. The Samagra Shiksha State Implementation Societynow invites eligible non-government organizations (“Consultants”) to indicate their interest in providing the services. This expression of Interest is only open to Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs).Interested NGOsshould provide information demonstrating that they have the required qualifications and relevant experience to perform the Services. Theshort-listing criteria are:

 

  • General experience of the Firm(s);
    • Experience in similar projects of compatible size, complexity and technical specialty in the required area;
    • Financial Soundness of the firm; and
    • Staffing and logistics of the firm.

While indicating information relating to (b), it shall be made clear whether responsibility of the firm was in the capacity of a principal firm (lead partner) or as an associated firm (sub-consultant/JV partner) with detail scope of the service.

 

Consultants are requested to submit the following supporting documents against the above-mentioned criteria:(a) Registration paper of the firm(s); (b) JV agreement/letter of intent (if applicable); (c) Firm’s brochure; (d) Audited financial reports for last three years; (e) service experience record (including nature, total cost, total input in terms of staff month, employer, location of service, scope of services etc.). The experience of a parent company, subsidiary company, group company or associates (whatever the names) of the Applicant shall not be considered in evaluation. 

 

4. The attention of interested Consultants is drawn to paragraphs 3.14, 3.16, and 3.17 of the “World Bank Procurement Regulations, 2016” for IPF Borrowers (Revised November 2020), setting forth the World Bank’s policy on conflict of interest. 

 

5. Consultants may associate with other firms in the form of a joint venture or a sub-consultancy to enhance their qualifications. In the case of an association, all members of such “association” should have real and well-defined inputs to the assignment and the total number of firms including their associates shall be maximum of three. In case of association in the form of sub-consultancy, the experience of sub-consultant shall not be considered in evaluation.

 

6. A Consultant will be selected in accordance with the Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) method as set out in Section VII, paragraph 7.3 of the World Bank’s “Procurement Regulations for IPF Borrowers” July 2016, revised August 2018 (“Procurement Regulations”).

 

7. The detailed Terms of Reference for the assignment can be found at the following website:schooledu.ap.gov.in (under “ World bank” tab).

 

8. Further information can be obtained at the address below during office hours. Queries may also be mailed at k.vetriselvi@gmail.com, with the subject line – “Query_SCERT Support Agency_<Name of the Firm>”.Please account for delays in response to queries.

 

9. Expressions of interest must be emailed/mailed at k.vetriselvi@gmail.comwith the subject line – “EoI_SCERT Support Agency_<Name of the firm>” by 23.59 Hrs 8th February 2021.

Theshort-listing criteria are:

 

    • General experience of the Firm(s);
    • Experience in similar projects of compatible size, complexity and technical specialty in the required area;
    • Financial Soundness of the firm; and
    • Staffing and logistics of the firm.

 

While indicating information relating to (b), it shall be made clear whether responsibility of the firm was in the capacity of a principal firm (lead partner) or as an associated firm (sub-consultant/JV partner) with detail scope of the service.

 

Consultants are requested to submit the following supporting documents against the above-mentioned criteria:(a) Registration paper of the firm(s); (b) JV agreement/letter of intent (if applicable); (c) Firm’s brochure; (d) Audited financial reports for last three years; (e) service experience record (including nature, total cost, total input in terms of staff month, employer, location of service, scope of services etc.). The experience of a parent company, subsidiary company, group company or associates (whatever the names) of the Applicant shall not be considered in evaluation. 

 

4. The attention of interested Consultants is drawn to paragraphs 3.14, 3.16, and 3.17 of the “World Bank Procurement Regulations, 2016” for IPF Borrowers (Revised November 2020), setting forth the World Bank’s policy on conflict of interest. 

 

5. Consultants may associate with other firms in the form of a joint venture or a sub-consultancy to enhance their qualifications. In the case of an association, all members of such “association” should have real and well-defined inputs to the assignment and the total number of firms including their associates shall be maximum of three. In case of association in the form of sub-consultancy, the experience of sub-consultant shall not be considered in evaluation.

 

6. A Consultant will be selected in accordance with the Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) method as set out in Section VII, paragraph 7.3 of the World Bank’s “Procurement Regulations for IPF Borrowers” July 2016, revised August 2018 (“Procurement Regulations”).

 

7. The detailed Terms of Reference for the assignment can be found at the following web link : schooled.ap.gov.in (under “ World Bank” tab)

 

8. Further information can be obtained at the address below during office hours. Queries may also be mailed at k.vetriselvi@gmail.com, with the subject line – “Query _PMU Support Agency_<Name of the Firm>”.Please account for delays in response to queries.

 

9. Expressions of interest must be emailed/mailed at k.vetriselvi@gmail.comwith the subject line – “EoI_PMU Support Agency_<Name of the firm>” by 23.59 Hrs 8th February 2021.

        "D34043185": {
            "id": "34043185",
            "docty": "Implementation Completion and Results Report",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34043185"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-04-12T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "Ratings for the Swachh Bharat Mission\n            Support Operation Project for India were as follows: outcome\n            and Bank performance was satisfactory, and monitoring and\n            evaluation (M and E) quality was substantial. Some lessons\n            learned included: strong leadership and a\n            whole-of-government approach were key enablers of successful\n            Swachh Bharat Mission - Gramin (SBM-G) implementation.\n            Successful program delivery requires strong institutional\n            capacity and systems at all levels. Program-for-results\n            (PforR) is an effective instrument for institutional\n            strengthening when integrated in the program results\n            framework. Open defecation free (ODF) sustainability will\n            require sustained efforts to promote behavior change and\n            infrastructure upkeep."
            },
            "display_title": "India - Swachh Bharat Mission\n            Support Operation Project",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099041423111515061/pdf/BOSIB015ca6285040822d0975196c5848f.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/projects/documents/2023/04/34043185/india-swachh-bharat-mission-support-operation-project",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099041423111515061/BOSIB015ca6285040822d0975196c5848f",
            "new_url": "2023/04/34043185/BOSIB015ca6285040822d0975196c5848f",
            "guid": "099041423111515061",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099041423111515061/BOSIB015ca6285040822d0975196c5848f"
        },

        "D34034989": {
            "id": "34034989",
            "docty": "Report",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34034989"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-04-04T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "India’s growth continued to\n            be resilient, despite some signs of a moderation in the\n            second half of FY22/23. Global economic activity slowed in\n            the second half of 2022 on the back of synchronized monetary\n            policy tightening, deteriorating financial conditions and\n            ongoing inflationary pressures. However, the reopening of\n            China’s economy and stronger than expected growth\n            outcomes in the United States and euro area at the end of\n            2022 are providing some tailwinds to growth in 2023.\n            Although significant challenges remain in the global\n            environment, India was one of the fastest growing economies\n            in the world with real GDP growing 7.7 percent year-on-year\n            during Q1-Q3 fiscal year 2022/23 (April-March, FY22/23).\n            Growth was underpinned by robust domestic demand\n            – strong investment activity bolstered by the\n            government’s capex push and buoyant private\n            consumption, particularly among higher income earners. While\n            the overall growth momentum remains robust and real GDP\n            growth for FY22/23 is estimated to be 6.9 percent, there\n            were signs of moderation in Q3 as growth slowed to 4.4\n            percent year-on-year (y-o-y). There was also a change in the\n            composition of domestic demand in Q3 FY22/23 with a lower\n            share from government consumption as fiscal consolidation\n            efforts continued. Estimates suggest that the pandemic\n            induced a spike in extreme poverty ($2.15), of up to 4\n            percentage points, moderated in FY21/22.1 Facilitated by\n            widespread access to vaccines, extreme poverty rates are\n            estimated to have declined to 13.8 percent in FY21/22,\n            although not as low as pre-pandemic levels. Continued\n            poverty reduction in FY22/23 will depend on how the economic\n            rebound translates into productive jobs for the bottom half\n            of the population and the welfare implications of fiscal\n            consolidation efforts."
            },
            "display_title": "India Development Update",

            "new_url": "2023/04/34034989/IDU05899cc410fae104e1708fed09a0345ca6f6c",

        "D34041777": {
            "id": "34041777",
            "docty": "Brief",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34041777"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-04-01T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "India has been one of the\n            fastest-growing major economies in the world, but growth in\n            FY23-24 will moderate on the back of global spillovers and\n            slower consumption growth. Lower demand-pull pressures and\n            monetary policy tightening will bring down inflation. Fiscal\n            consolidation will stabilize public debt around 83 percent.\n            Although extreme and moderate poverty remain above\n            pre-pandemic levels, they are expected to decline in\n            FY22-23. Over 40 percent of the population still lives in\n            moderate poverty (3.65 US dollars per person per day). This\n            Macro Poverty Outlook presents GDP, debt and fiscal\n            forecasts and examines the implications for critical\n            economic and social concepts such as growth, poverty\n            reduction and macroeconomic stability."
            },
            "display_title": "Macro Poverty Outlook for India :\n            April 2023",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099926404122337433/pdf/IDU0fdc10b4008f8e04b7c0b1060c253d253f63a.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/04/34041777/macro-poverty-outlook-india-april-2023",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099926404122337433/IDU0fdc10b4008f8e04b7c0b1060c253d253f63a",
            "new_url": "2023/04/34041777/IDU0fdc10b4008f8e04b7c0b1060c253d253f63a",
            "guid": "099926404122337433",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099926404122337433/IDU0fdc10b4008f8e04b7c0b1060c253d253f63a"
        },
        "D34046159": {
            "id": "34046159",
            "docty": "Brief",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34046159"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-04-01T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "Women are key in the sugarcane industry\n            and have an untapped potential to contribute to the growth\n            of the sector. IFC MAS Advisory worked with DCM Shriram and\n            Olam India to narrow the gap in access to training for\n            sustainable climate practices and support\n            farmers—men and women—in water\n            management, soil health, and climate resilient agriculture\n            practices. The companies are ideal partners considering\n            their potential to scale the initiative. DCM Shriram Sugar\n            Mills runs four sugar mills located in Hardoi, Uttar\n            Pradesh, one of the poorest and most disadvantaged districts\n            in the country. It covers more than 100,000 Ha and employs\n            200,000 farmers. Olam India, a leading food and\n            agribusiness, runs two sugar mills in Bharwani (Madhya\n            Pradesh) and Rajgoli (Maharashtra) covering more than 20,000\n            Ha and employing 57,000 farmers."
            },
            "display_title": "Untapping the Potential of the\n            Sugarcane Sector in India",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099919504202337676/pdf/IDU011a5e7b706e80043000b2250ab372f6663e7.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/04/34046159/untapping-potential-sugarcane-sector-india",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099919504202337676/IDU011a5e7b706e80043000b2250ab372f6663e7",
            "new_url": "2023/04/34046159/IDU011a5e7b706e80043000b2250ab372f6663e7",
            "guid": "099919504202337676",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099919504202337676/IDU011a5e7b706e80043000b2250ab372f6663e7"
        },
        "D33859449": {
            "id": "33859449",
            "docty": "Brief",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "33859449"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-04-01T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "This briefing showcases the gender\n            landscape in India on key indicators helpful for monitoring\n            gender equality and designing effective policy\n            interventions. Gender equality fosters productivity gains,\n            minimizes losses in wealth, reduces poverty, boosts shared\n            prosperity, and supports green, resilient, and inclusive development."
            },
            "display_title": "India Gender Landscape",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099116007012231127/pdf/IDU098b40b9e0f0b6043ec0b51d07c00e31478db.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/04/33859449/india-gender-landscape",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099116007012231127/IDU098b40b9e0f0b6043ec0b51d07c00e31478db",

        },

        "D34029330": {
            "id": "34029330",
            "docty": "Policy Research Working Paper",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34029330"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-03-27T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "This paper uses an exogenous shock to\n            wages from the world’s largest anti-poverty\n            program to show that higher wages can lead to increased air\n            pollution, likely by inducing farmers to shift into a\n            labor-saving and mechanized production process. Using a\n            difference-in-differences approach on the staggered roll-out\n            of India’s Mahatma Gandhi National Rural\n            Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA), combined with data on\n            nearly 1 million fires, the paper shows that the frequency\n            of agricultural fires increases by 21 percent after the\n            shock. The increase in fires is concentrated in districts\n            that appear more likely to mechanize the harvest. MNREGA did\n            not lead to changes in area planted or tonnage produced in\n            fire intensive crops. The estimates show that nationally,\n            the shock increased the rate of particulate emissions from\n            biomass burning by 30 to 50 percent. The results suggest\n            that absent policies to correct for environmental\n            externalities of mechanization at all stages of development,\n            labor market shocks may lead to inefficient levels of mechanization."
            },
            "display_title": "Man or Machine ? Environmental\n            Consequences of Wage Driven Mechanization in Indian Agriculture",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099331103272325045/pdf/IDU048f582490193f040690aa5e0f520e1b96a3f.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/03/34029330/man-or-machine-environmental-consequences-wage-driven-mechanization-indian-agriculture",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099331103272325045/IDU048f582490193f040690aa5e0f520e1b96a3f",
            "new_url": "2023/03/34029330/IDU048f582490193f040690aa5e0f520e1b96a3f",
            "guid": "099331103272325045",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099331103272325045/IDU048f582490193f040690aa5e0f520e1b96a3f"
        },

        "D34022828": {
            "id": "34022828",
            "docty": "Policy Research Working Paper",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34022828"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-03-16T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "This paper examines the impact of\n            Covid-19 on a host of labor market outcomes in India, using\n            a continuous household survey. Cross-sectional trends of\n            headline indicators like unemployment and labor force\n            participation indicate a quick recovery after the\n            unprecedented shock of the pandemic. However, women,\n            marginalized social groups, and youth were more adversely\n            affected, largely due to the nature of their employment\n            before the pandemic. Next, a fixed-cohort analysis with a\n            difference-in-differences regression framework is used to\n            follow the labor market trajectories of a Covid-affected\n            cohort and a pre-Covid cohort for comparison, over a span of\n            12-16 months. A story of downward transitions emerges, with\n            movements out of the labor force, into more informal and\n            lower-paid types of work in agriculture and rural areas.\n            Higher education and being located in dense, urban areas\n            partially mediated the adverse shocks of Covid-19. Lastly,\n            India’s extensive vaccination campaign had\n            significant positive impacts on employment recovery."
            },
            "display_title": "Synthesis of the Impacts of\n            Covid-19 on Indias Labor Market : Looking at People, Places\n            and Policies",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099335003162316683/pdf/IDU0033327e00090c04ed90b88900e2290079692.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/03/34022828/synthesis-impacts-covid-19-indias-labor-market-looking-people-places-policies",

        "D34022732": {
            "id": "34022732",
            "docty": "Resettlement Plan",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34022732"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-03-15T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "The objective of the Green National\n            Highways Corridor Project for India is to enhance the\n            institutional capacity of Ministry of Road Transport and\n            Highways in improving transport connectivity through\n            adopting green and climate resilient construction methods\n            for the National Highway network and implementing them in\n            pilot sections of the Network. This project is a part of\n            Green National Highway Corridor Project (GNHCP), for which a\n            RPF has been prepared based on the findings of Social Survey\n            Report (SSR) covering initial impact assessment and review\n            of applicable legal and policy framework. In order to\n            address the adverse impacts of land acquisition and\n            involuntary resettlement in GNHCP sub-projects, MoRTH, Govt.\n            of India recognized the need for the development of\n            Resettlement Policy Framework. Review of Social Screening\n            Reports (SSRs) reveal that applicable legal and\n            administrative procedures vary from State to State and also\n            there are gaps between Resettlement and Rehabilitation\n            Policies of the country and certain states and the\n            Bank’s Resettlement Policy. Hence, there is a\n            need to understand the critical elements of the existing\n            legal and policy framework and agree on a mechanism that\n            will address the key social issues and formulate a specific\n            policy framework for the project to bridge the major gaps to\n            conform to the provisions of World Bank’s\n            operational policies related to Involuntary Resettlement and\n            Indigenous Peoples. This policy framework will help expedite\n            the process and facilitate consistent preparation of ARAPs\n            across all project roads in different states."
            },
            "display_title": "India - Green National Highways\n            Corridor Project : Resettlement Plan : Rehabilitation and\n            Upgradation to Two Lane with Paved Shoulder Configurations\n            ofto Koyyuru -Paderu Road Section of NH-516E in the State of\n            Andhra Pradesh",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099082503162317147/pdf/P1673500609e0d0c209f990aba4bb8d2196.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/projects/documents/2023/03/34022732/india-green-national-highways-corridor-project-resettlement-plan-rehabilitation-upgradation-two-lane-paved-shoulder-configurations-ofto-koyyuru--paderu-road-section-nh-516e-state-andhra-pradesh",

        "D34021391": {
            "id": "34021391",
            "docty": "Report",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34021391"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-03-14T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "India has one of the largest and\n            fastest-growing tertiary education systems in the world. The\n            system enrolls 37 million students across nearly 50,000\n            institutions. The recently endorsed National Education\n            Policy (NEP) aims at a further doubling of the gross\n            enrollment ratio in higher education from 26.3 percent to 50\n            percent by 2035. Despite its size and growth rate, and the\n            emphasis placed on tertiary education by Indian policymakers\n            in recent times, the system has faced continuous challenges\n            of equitable access, quality, governance, and financing,\n            with the quality of inputs and outputs not keeping pace with\n            the expansion of the sector. The World Bank has supported\n            tertiary education in India through a series of engagements\n            in technical education at the national level, and general\n            tertiary education in specific states. The NEP’s\n            proposal for broad-based tertiary education reforms as a key\n            step toward transforming the tertiary education sector in\n            India aligns with the Bank’s global tertiary\n            education strategy and presents an opportunity for the\n            Bank’s engagement in this area through analytic\n            work, dialogue with key stakeholders, and strategic\n            engagement with states and tertiary education institutions.\n            Based on this analysis, the World Bank in 2020-2021 expanded\n            its engagement in Indian tertiary education through\n            dedicated analytical and advisory work in the NEP context.\n            Focusing on the areas of access and equity, employability,\n            digitalization, internationalization, academic careers,\n            governance, funding, as well as quality assurance, the World\n            Bank conducted a series of virtual events and prepared\n            technical reports discussing the status quo in Indian\n            tertiary education in the context of the proposed NEP\n            reforms and international trends. The report at hand\n            provides a summary of the outcomes of this work."
            },
            "display_title": "From Good to Great in Indian\n            Tertiary Education : Realizing the Promise of the National\n            Education Policy",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099080503142332315/pdf/P1747790711faf048085a70993d530a04de.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/03/34021391/good-great-indian-tertiary-education-realizing-promise-national-education-policy",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099080503142332315/P1747790711faf048085a70993d530a04de",
            "new_url": "2023/03/34021391/P1747790711faf048085a70993d530a04de",
            "guid": "099080503142332315",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099080503142332315/P1747790711faf048085a70993d530a04de"
        },

        "D34019229": {
            "id": "34019229",
            "docty": "Brief",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34019229"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-03-13T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "A World Bank report on the Indian\n            highway sector (World Bank 2002) put the spotlight on state\n            highways agencies and networks. This critical\n            “middle” layer of the network is\n            between the national highway system and the village roads\n            providing basic access. While both the national and\n            last-mile layers had and still attract a lot of attention\n            from the national government, the state highway system is\n            managed by the states with no national attention or funding.\n            This middle layer was and remains critical to\n            India’s economic and social aspirations: to\n            connect agricultural goods and small and medium-scale\n            enterprise (SMSE) outputs to markets to bring goods to rural\n            India. This feeder network providing crucial interlinkages,\n            connectivity, and access accounts for around 3 percent of\n            the total network length, carrying 40 percent of total\n            traffic (medium to heavy). However, almost 60 percent of\n            this network has a carriageway width of less than the\n            two-lane standard. The five states of Maharashtra,\n            Karnataka, Gujarat, Rajasthan, and Andhra Pradesh account\n            for 56 percent of total length of state highways in India."
            },
            "display_title": "India State Roads Sector : Ten\n            Key Insights",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099551303102317434/pdf/IDU0a272f55e0902304aa80a31609b8863916778.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/03/34019229/india-state-roads-sector-ten-key-insights",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099551303102317434/IDU0a272f55e0902304aa80a31609b8863916778",
            "new_url": "2023/03/34019229/IDU0a272f55e0902304aa80a31609b8863916778",
            "guid": "099551303102317434",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099551303102317434/IDU0a272f55e0902304aa80a31609b8863916778"

        "D34018153": {
            "id": "34018153",
            "docty": "Project Appraisal Document",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34018153"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-03-03T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "The development objective of the Assam\n            Integrated River Basin Management Program for India is to\n            reduce the vulnerability of people to climate-related\n            disasters and improve integrated water resources management\n            in Assam. The project comprises of four components. The\n            first component, institutional strengthening and strategic\n            studies focuses on institutional strengthening of Water\n            Resources Department (WRD) and Assam State Disaster\n            Management Authority (ASDMA). It consists of following\n            sub-components: (i) institutional strengthening of WRD; (ii)\n            institutional strengthening of ASDMA; and (iii) Flood and\n            River Erosion Management Agency of Assam (FREMAA) project\n            management and incremental costs. The second component,\n            water resources management finances the structural and\n            non-structural activities to reduce flood and river erosion\n            risk. It consists of following sub-components: (i) river\n            works investments; (ii) flood forecasting, integrated flood\n            risk management plan (IFRMPs), and investment preparation;\n            (iii) data collection and embankment asset management; (iv)\n            Assam water center annex; and (v) WRD Project management and\n            incremental costs. The third component, disaster risk\n            management will help Assam improve its disaster mitigation,\n            preparedness, response, and recovery capacity. It consists\n            of following sub-components: (i) flood shelters; (ii) early\n            warning and dissemination system; (iii) capacity building of\n            circle quick response teams; (iv) climate resilient\n            villages; and (v) ASDMA project management and incremental\n            costs. The fourth component, contingent emergency response\n            will provide immediate response to an eligible crisis or\n            emergency, as needed."
            },
            "display_title": "India - Assam Integrated River\n            Basin Management Program",

        "D34027767": {
            "id": "34027767",
            "docty": "Implementation Completion and Results Report",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34027767"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-02-28T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "Ratings for the National Ganga River\n            Basin Project for India were as follows: outcome was\n            satisfactory, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,\n            and monitoring and evaluation (M and E) quality was\n            substantial. Some lessons learned included: an\n            operation’s financing envelope should represent a\n            balance between long-term ambition and the existing\n            absorptive capacity of the client. Support of high-level\n            political champions is necessary to build momentum for\n            change but achieving development outcomes requires an\n            appropriate administrative architecture and operational and\n            field-level champions. Readiness assessments for\n            institutional development programs should factor in the\n            relevance of activities to project objectives, the legacy of\n            past attempts at capacity building, and the willingness of\n            the concerned institutions. Creation and strengthening of\n            new institutions take time and, as the National Mission for\n            Clean Ganga (NMCG) case illustrates, a steady and iterative\n            increase in staffing, mandate, authority, and experience\n            gained from learning-by-doing. The hybrid annuity model -\n            public private partnership (HAM-PPP) model, jointly\n            developed by the World Bank and International Finance\n            Corporation (IFC), is an important contractual innovation\n            for the wastewater sector - it tackles the perennial\n            challenge of operations and maintenance and contributes to\n            enhanced operational sustainability. Increasing\n            sustainability of wastewater infrastructure and services is\n            a complex undertaking that requires mobilization of multiple\n            stakeholders, investments at multiple institutional levels,\n            and improvements in all aspects of planning, design, and implementation."
            },
            "display_title": "India - National Ganga River\n            Basin Project",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099223503232338933/pdf/BOSIB084ec3fe70f40a36b024e3136ec486.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/projects/documents/2023/02/34027767/india-national-ganga-river-basin-project",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099223503232338933/BOSIB084ec3fe70f40a36b024e3136ec486",
            "new_url": "2023/02/34027767/BOSIB084ec3fe70f40a36b024e3136ec486",
            "guid": "099223503232338933",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099223503232338933/BOSIB084ec3fe70f40a36b024e3136ec486"
        },

                "entityid": "34018922"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-02-27T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "Ratings for the Integrated Child\n            Development Services (ICDS) Systems Strengthening and\n            Nutrition Improvement Project (ISSNIP) for India were as\n            follows: outcome and Bank performance was satisfactory, and\n            monitoring and evaluation (M and E) quality was substantial.\n            Some lessons learned included: using performance, results,\n            and incentives as motivation instead of input-based\n            financing paid off. Effective and sustainable capacity\n            building of program functionaries and frontliners. The ICDS\n            -common application software (CAS) mobile technology for\n            nutrition service was among the first such systems to be\n            developed for a nutrition program. Community-based events\n            (CBEs), prioritized home visits, innovations, mass, and\n            mid-media campaigns all contributed to improved knowledge\n            and behavior among beneficiaries. The project innovations\n            were mainstreamed into Prime Minister’s\n            Overarching Scheme of Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) 2.0;\n            hence those innovations were sustained beyond the end of the\n            project. Finally, improving nutrition requires long term\n            sustained intensive, harmonized engagement, and additional\n            in-depth analysis on complementary feeding indicators\n            lagging in certain states."
            },
            "display_title": "India - ICDS Systems\n            Strengthening and Nutrition Improvement Project (ISSNIP)",

        "D34010929": {
            "id": "34010929",
            "docty": "President's Speech",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34010929"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-02-25T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "These remarks were delivered by World\n            Bank Group President David Malpass at the Global Sovereign\n            Debt Roundtable in Bengaluru, India on February 25, 2023.\n            The goal of these roundtable meetings is to have open\n            discussions, help identify barriers to debt restructurings,\n            and develop steps to improve the process. The World Bank is\n            committed to providing net positive flows in a way that\n            maximizes concessionally in the restructuring process. He\n            will provide as much concessionally to the debt treatment as\n            possible. The issues can be complex, and we will work with\n            you on measuring concessionally and the comparable treatment\n            among creditors and see how we can make progress on the debt\n            treatment. The World Bank is putting on the table to be as\n            concessional as possible to achieve debt treatments by\n            creditors. In the instance of Chad, which worked through the\n            Common Framework, we have been providing 100 percent grants.\n            The concessionally there has been massive. By providing\n            resources, we are lowering the amount needed by creditors\n            for restructuring, benefitting all the creditors. Some 70\n            percent of IDA resources go to Sub-Saharan Africa, many in\n            unsustainable debt situations. Our concessionally is large\n            here and directly benefits creditors during restructurings."
            },
            "display_title": "Remarks by World Bank Group\n            President David Malpass at the Global Sovereign Debt\n            Roundtable in Bengaluru, India",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099943303012321762/pdf/IDU00468a07b010d0a65f01a696c235a9b.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/research/2023/02/34010929/remarks-world-bank-group-president-david-malpass-global-sovereign-debt-roundtable-bengaluru-india",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099943303012321762/IDU00468a07b010d0a65f01a696c235a9b",
            "new_url": "2023/02/34010929/IDU00468a07b010d0a65f01a696c235a9b",
            "guid": "099943303012321762",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099943303012321762/IDU00468a07b010d0a65f01a696c235a9b"
        },
        "D34010923": {
            "id": "34010923",
            "docty": "President's Speech",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34010923"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-02-25T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "These remarks were delivered by World\n            Bank Group President David Malpass at the G20 Finance and\n            Central Bank Governors’ Meeting in Bengaluru,\n            India on February 25, 2023. He spoke about the global\n            economy and health. On trade and investment, governments\n            should avoid imposing export restrictions in response to\n            food and energy shocks. Non-tariff barriers are being\n            raised, which will distort trade and slow growth. Subsidies\n            should be targeted, and time bound. We should also increase\n            the support for people affected by conflict or food\n            insecurity, particularly in low-income countries. Fiscal\n            consolidation is necessary and should be guided by credible\n            medium-term frameworks, with a focus on reducing wasteful\n            spending and inefficient agricultural and fuel subsidies.\n            The international community needs to help reduce the risk of\n            debt crises in developing countries by supporting timely\n            debt restructurings."
            },
            "display_title": "Remarks by World Bank Group\n            President David Malpass at the G20 Finance and Central Bank\n            Governors Meeting in Bengaluru, India  Session 3 : Global\n            Economy and Health",

        "D34010920": {
            "id": "34010920",
            "docty": "President's Speech",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34010920"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-02-24T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "These remarks were delivered by World\n            Bank Group President David Malpass at the G20 Finance and\n            Central Bank Governors’ Meeting in Bengaluru,\n            India on February 24, 2023. He spoke about the financial\n            sector and inclusion. Well-designed payment systems, digital\n            ID, and data sharing systems have been key to targeting and\n            delivering benefits to individuals and MSMEs during the\n            COVID-19 pandemic. He takes full note of India’s\n            success in this regard and its astounding advances in\n            digital payments. He is pleased to contribute to this\n            Presidency agenda and share our insights from our programs\n            such as ID4D, Fast Payments, and GovTech in countries from\n            the Philippines and Morocco to the Eastern Caribbeans.\n            Greater investment in private sectors will be key."
            },

        "D34007132": {
            "id": "34007132",
            "docty": "Investigation Report",
            "entityids": {
                "entityid": "34007132"
            },
            "docdt": "2023-02-20T00:00:00Z",
            "abstracts": {
                "cdata!": "This is the eighth progress report to\n            the Board of Executive Directors on the implementation of\n            the management action plan (MAP) in response to the\n            Inspection Panel Investigation Report on the India Vishnugad\n            Pipalkoti Hydro Electric Project. On August 3, 2012, the\n            Inspection Panel registered a Request for Inspection\n            concerning the Vishnugad Pipalkoti Hydro Electric Project\n            (VPHEP). The Request was submitted by residents of Chamoli\n            district in the State of Uttarakhand (the Requesters).\n            Management responded to the claims in the Request on October\n            24, 2012. In its report to the Board, the Panel found the\n            request eligible and recommended that the Executive\n            Directors authorize an investigation. On July 1, 2014, the\n            Panel issued its report outlining the findings of its\n            investigation, and this, along with management’s\n            report and recommendation, including the action plan, was\n            discussed at the Board on September 30, 2014."
            },
            "display_title": "India - Vishnugad Pipalkoti Hydro\n            Electric Project : Eighth Progress Report on the\n            Implementation of Managements Action Plan in Response to\n            the Inspection Panel Investigation Report",
            "pdfurl": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099222002212341004/pdf/BOSIB0acacfbe205e0ace40d6f692de1008.pdf",
            "listing_relative_url": "/projects/documents/2023/02/34007132/india-vishnugad-pipalkoti-hydro-electric-project-eighth-progress-report-implementation-managements-action-plan-response-inspection-panel-investigation-report",
            "url_friendly_title": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099222002212341004/BOSIB0acacfbe205e0ace40d6f692de1008",
            "new_url": "2023/02/34007132/BOSIB0acacfbe205e0ace40d6f692de1008",
            "guid": "099222002212341004",
            "url": "http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/099222002212341004/BOSIB0acacfbe205e0ace40d6f692de1008"
        },
